chapter.title: Deploying with &cephadm;
chapter.para: To deploy a &ceph; cluster by using &cephadm;, you need to complete the following tasks:

listitem.para: Install and do basic configuration of the underlying operating system—&cephos;—on all cluster nodes.
Deploy the &salt; infrastructure over all cluster nodes so that you can orchestrate them effectively.
Configure the basic properties of the cluster and deploy it.

tip.title: Install &productname; Together with &sls;

sect1.title: Deploy &salt;
sect1.para: &productname; uses &salt; as a cluster orchestrator. &salt; helps you configure and run commands on multiple cluster nodes simultaneously from one dedicated host called the &smaster;. Before deploying &salt;, consider the following important points:

listitem.para: &sminion;s are the nodes controlled by a dedicated node called &smaster;. &sminion;s have roles, for example &osd;, &mon;, &mgr;, &rgw;, &igw;, or &ganesha;.

A &smaster; runs its own &sminion;. It is required for running privileged tasks—for example creating, authorizing, and copying keys to minions—so that remote minions never need to run privileged tasks.

tip.title: Sharing Multiple Roles per Server
tip.para: You will get the best performance from your &ceph; cluster when each role is deployed on a separate node. But real deployments sometimes require sharing one node for multiple roles. To avoid trouble with performance and the upgrade procedure, do not deploy the &osd;, &mds;, or &mon; role to the &adm;.

listitem.para: &sminion;s need to correctly resolve the &smaster;'s host name over the network. By default, they look for the salt host name, but you can specify any other network-reachable host name in the /etc/salt/minion file.

If you intend to use the firewall, verify that the &smaster; node has ports 4505 and 4506 open to all &sminion; nodes. If the ports are closed, you can open them using the yast2 firewall command by allowing the SaltStack service.

Make sure that the fully qualified domain name of each node can be resolved to an IP address on the public cluster network by all the other nodes.

sect2.title: Configure Cluster Properties
sect2.para: Use the ceph-salt config command to configure the basic properties of the cluster.

sect3.title: &cephsalt; Shell
sect3.para: If you run ceph-salt config without any path or subcommand, you will enter an interactive &cephsalt; shell. The shell is convenient if you need to configure multiple properties in one batch and do not want type the full command syntax.

As you can see from the output of &cephsalt;'s ls command, the cluster configuration is organized in a tree structure. To configure a specific property of the cluster in the &cephsalt; shell, you have two options:

listitem.para: Change to the path whose property you need to configure and run the command:
listitem.screen: /> cd /ceph_cluster/minions/ /ceph_cluster/minions> ls o- minions .................................................. [Minions: 5] o- ses-master.example.com ................................... [no roles] o- ses-min1.example.com ..................................... [no roles] [...]

listitem.para: Run the command from the current position and enter the absolute path to the property as the first argument:

tip.title: Autocompletion of Configuration Snippets
tip.para: While in a &cephsalt; shell, you can use the autocompletion feature similar to a normal Linux shell (Bash) autocompletion. It completes configuration paths, subcommands, or &sminion; names. When autocompleting a configuration path, you have two options:

listitem.para: To let the shell finish a path relative to your current position, hit the TAB key twice.
To let the shell finish an absolute path, enter / and hit the TAB key twice.

tip.title: Navigating with the Cursor Keys
tip.para: If you enter cd from the &cephsalt; shell without any path, the command will print a tree structure of the cluster configuration with the line of the current path active. You can use the up and down cursor keys to navigate through individual lines. After you confirm with , the configuration path will change to the last active one.

[Minions: 5] o- ses-master.example.com .................................. [no roles] o- ses-min1.example.com .................................... sect3.title: Specify &adm;
sect3.para: The &adm; is the host where the ceph.conf configuration file and the &ceph; admin keyring is installed. You usually run &ceph; related commands on the &adm;.

tip.title: &smaster; and &adm; on the Same Host
tip.para: In a homogeneous environment where all or most nodes belong to &productname;, we recommend having the &adm; on the same host as the &smaster;.
In a heterogeneous environment where one &salt; infrastructure hosts more than one cluster, for example, &productname; together with &susemgr;, do not place the &adm; on the same host as &smaster;.

sect3.para: To specify the &adm;, run the following command:
sect3.screen: &prompt.smaster;ceph-salt config ceph-salt config /ceph_cluster/roles/admin add ses-master.example.com 1 minion added. &prompt.smaster;ceph-salt config /ceph_cluster/roles/admin ls o- admin ................................................... [Minions: 1] o- ses-master.example.com ............................ [no other roles]

tip.title: Install ceph.conf and the Admin Keyring on Multiple Nodes
tip.para: You can install the &ceph; configuration file and admin keyring on multiple nodes if you deployment requires it. For security reasons, avoid installing them on all the cluster's nodes.

sect3.title: Specify First MON/MGR Node
sect3.screen: &prompt.smaster;ceph-salt config /ceph_cluster/roles/bootstrap set ses-min1.example.com Value set. &prompt.smaster;ceph-salt config /ceph_cluster/roles/bootstrap ls o- bootstrap ..................................... [ses-min1.example.com]

tip.para: The minion that will bootstrap the cluster needs to have the admin keyring as well:
tip.screen: &smaster;ceph-salt config ceph-salt config /ceph_cluster/roles/admin add ses-min1.example.com 1 minion added. &prompt.smaster;ceph-salt config /ceph_cluster/roles/admin ls o- admin ................................................... [Minions: 1] o- ses-master.example.com ............................ [no other roles] o- ses-min1.suse.cz .......................... [other roles: bootstrap]

sect3.title: Generate SSH Key Pair
sect3.para: &cephadm; uses the SSH protocol to communicate with cluster nodes. You need to generate the private and public part of the SSH key pair:
sect3.screen: &prompt.smaster;ceph-salt config /ssh generate Key pair generated. &prompt.smaster;ceph-salt config /ssh ls o- ssh ................................................... [Key Pair set] o- private_key ...... [53:b1:eb:65:d2:3a:ff:51:6c:e2:1b:ca:84:8e:0e:83] o- public_key ....... [53:b1:eb:65:d2:3a:ff:51:6c:e2:1b:ca:84:8e:0e:83]

sect3.title: Configure Time Server
sect3.para: Select one of the &sminion;s to be a time server for the rest of the cluster, and configure it to synchronize its time with a reliable time source(s). Verify that the time synchronization service is enabled on each cluster node on system start-up.
sect3.screen: &prompt.smaster;ceph-salt config /time_server/server_hostname set ses-master.example.com &prompt.smaster;ceph-salt config /time_server/external_servers add 0.pt.pool.ntp.org &prompt.smaster;ceph-salt config /time_server ls o- time_server ................................................ [enabled] o- external_servers ............................................... [1] | o- 0.pt.pool.ntp.org .......................................... [...] o- server_hostname ........................... [ses-master.example.com]
sect3.para: Find more information on setting up time synchronization in .

sect1.title: Further Deployment and Administration (Day 2)
sect1.para: After you have deployed the basic &ceph; cluster, you need to deploy core services on more cluster nodes. To make the cluster data accessible to clients, deploy additional services.

sect2.title: The ceph orch Command
sect2.para: The &ceph; orchestrator command ceph orch—which is an interface to the &cephadm; module—will take care of listing cluster components and deploying &ceph; services on new cluster nodes.

sect3.title: Displaying the Orchestrator Status
sect3.para: The following command shows the current mode and status of the &ceph; orchestrator. It also show actions that are currently in progress.

sect3.title: Listing Devices, Services, and Daemons
sect3.para: To run ceph-volume on all nodes and list all disk devices, run:
sect3.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph orch device ls HOST PATH TYPE SIZE DEVICE AVAIL REJECT REASONS ses-master /dev/vda hdd 16.0G False locked ses-min1 /dev/vdb hdd 20.0G True ses-min1 /dev/vda hdd 16.0G False locked ses-min2 /dev/vdb hdd 20.0G True [...]

tip.title: Services and Daemons
tip.para: Service is a general term for a &ceph; service of a specific type, for example &mgr;.
Daemon is a specific instance of a service, for example a process mgr.ses-min1.gdlcik running on a host called ses-min1.

sect3.para: To list all services known to &cephadm;, run:
sect3.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph orch ls NAME RUNNING REFRESHED AGE PLACEMENT IMAGE NAME IMAGE ID mgr 1/0 5m ago - <no spec> registry.example.com/[...] 5bf12403d0bd mon 1/0 5m ago - <no spec> registry.example.com/[...] 5bf12403d0bd

tip.para: You can limit the list to services on a particular host with the optional –host parameter and services of a particular type with the optional –type parameter (accepts mon, osd, mgr, mds, and rgw).

sect3.para: To list all running daemons deployed by &cephadm;, run:
sect3.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph orch ps NAME HOST STATUS REFRESHED AGE VERSION IMAGE ID CONTAINER ID mgr.ses-min1.gdlcik ses-min1 running (5d) 8m ago 12d 15.2.0.108 5bf12403d0bd b8104e09814c mon.ses-min1 ses-min1 running (5d) 8m ago 12d 15.2.0.108 5bf12403d0bd a719e0087369

tip.para: To query the status of a particular daemon, use --daemon_type and --daemon_id. For OSDs, the ID is the numeric OSD ID. For MDS, the ID is the file system name:
tip.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph orch ps --daemon_type osd --daemon_id 0 &prompt.cephuser;ceph orch ps --daemon_type mds --daemon_id my_cephfs

sect2.title: Upgrading &ceph;
sect2.para: You can instruct &cephadm; to upgrade &ceph; from one bugfix release to another. The automated upgrade of &ceph; services respects the recommended order—it starts with &mgr;s, &mon;s, and then continues on other services such as &osd;s, &mds;s, and &ogw;s. Each daemon is restarted only after &ceph; indicates that the cluster will remain available.
